definitions: restore something to a fresh or original condition by replacing or repairing worn parts
extend the period of validity of a license subscription or contract
begin something again after a pause or interruption has occurred
examples: The company decided to renew all the old office furniture
Spring weather helped renew her energy and enthusiasm
Remember to renew your driver's license before it expires
They renewed their magazine subscription for another year
After the break they renewed their discussion with fresh perspectives
The two countries renewed diplomatic relations after years of tension

definitions: formally declare one's abandonment of a claim right or possession
refuse to continue recognizing or abiding by a belief habit or practice
examples: The prince renounced his claim to the throne yesterday
She renounced her citizenship to become a French national
The activist renounced violence as a means of protest
He publicly renounced his former political beliefs last year

definitions: repair and improve a building or structure to bring it back to good condition
modernize and update something old to meet contemporary standards and requirements
examples: They hired contractors to renovate the historic downtown theater
The couple spent months renovating their Victorian era house
The university plans to renovate all dormitories with modern amenities
The company renovated their business model for the digital age

definitions: pay someone for the use of property or equipment for a specified period
allow someone to use property or equipment in return for regular payment
tear or make a hole in something especially fabric or material
examples: They rent a small apartment near the university campus
We decided to rent a car for our vacation trip
The landlord rents out several properties in the neighborhood
She rents her spare room to international students
The explosion rent the air with its deafening sound
Strong winds rent the sail during the storm yesterday

definitions: open a place or establishment again after it has been closed temporarily
begin discussing or considering something again that was previously concluded or settled
examples: The museum will reopen next Monday after extensive renovations
Schools reopened in September following the summer vacation break
The judge agreed to reopen the case with new evidence
Parliament voted to reopen the debate on healthcare reform

definitions: change the structure or arrangement of an organization or system for improvement
arrange or order things differently to achieve better efficiency or effectiveness
examples: The company decided to reorganise its departments for better efficiency
They reorganised the entire supply chain management system last year
She reorganised her schedule to accommodate the new responsibilities
We need to reorganise these files in alphabetical order

definitions: change the way an organization or company is structured and operates
arrange something again in a different and usually more effective way
examples: The board voted to reorganize the company into three divisions
Management decided to reorganize after the merger was completed
She spent the weekend reorganizing her home office space
They reorganized the inventory system for faster product retrieval

definitions: apply a new coat of paint to something that was previously painted
cover a surface with fresh paint to restore or change its appearance
examples: They decided to repaint the house before putting it on sale
The city repaints the bridge every five years for maintenance
We need to repaint these old chairs to match the table
The artist repainted certain sections of the mural yesterday

definitions: fix or mend something that is broken damaged or not working properly
restore something abstract like a relationship or reputation to a better condition
examples: The mechanic repaired my car engine in just two hours
She learned how to repair computers at vocational school
They worked hard to repair their damaged friendship after the argument
The company tried to repair its reputation following the scandal

definitions: send someone back to their own country especially refugees or prisoners of war
transfer foreign earnings or profits back to one's own country of origin
examples: The government repatriated hundreds of refugees to their homeland last month
Embassy officials helped repatriate stranded tourists during the crisis
Many corporations repatriate their overseas profits at year end
The company repatriated billions of dollars from foreign subsidiaries

definitions: pay back money that you have borrowed from someone or an institution
do or give something in return for a favor help or kindness received
examples: She promised to repay the loan within three years
The company must repay its debts before declaring bankruptcy
How can I ever repay your kindness and generosity?
He repaid their trust by working harder than ever before

definitions: officially revoke or annul a law regulation or act of parliament
formally cancel or withdraw an official decision decree or agreement
examples: Congress voted to repeal the controversial tax law last week
The government repealed the outdated regulation from the previous century
The board decided to repeal their earlier decision about bonuses
The council repealed the parking restrictions after public complaints

definitions: say or do something again often for emphasis or clarity purposes
happen or occur again in the same way or form as before
examples: Could you please repeat your question more slowly this time?
The teacher repeated the instructions three times for clarity
History tends to repeat itself in predictable patterns over time
The same mistakes repeated throughout the entire project timeline

definitions: drive back or away by force or influence especially an attack or enemy
cause someone to feel intense distaste disgust or aversion toward something
examples: The army successfully repelled the enemy attack at dawn yesterday
This spray repels mosquitoes and other insects for eight hours
His arrogant behavior repelled potential friends and business partners alike
The gruesome scene repelled even the most hardened investigators

definitions: feel or express sincere regret or remorse about one's wrongdoing or sin
feel regret about a decision and wish you had acted differently
examples: The prisoner repented his crimes during his years in jail
She went to church to repent and seek forgiveness
He soon repented his hasty decision to quit his job
They repented their harsh words spoken in anger yesterday

definitions: take the place of someone or something by providing a substitute or successor
put something back in its original position after removing or using it
examples: The company will replace all outdated computers next month
She replaced the retiring manager as department head
Remember to replace the cap on the bottle after use
He carefully replaced the book on the library shelf

definitions: play back a recording of something that has been previously recorded
play a game or match again especially because the first was inconclusive
examples: The coach asked them to replay the video of yesterday's game
She replayed the voicemail message to understand it better
The teams will replay the match next week due to weather
They had to replay the final after it ended in a draw

definitions: fill something up again after it has been emptied or depleted
restore a stock or supply of something to its former level or condition
examples: The waiter quickly replenished our water glasses during dinner
Rain will replenish the reservoir after months of drought
The store replenishes its inventory twice a week from the warehouse
She replenished her energy with a healthy snack and water

definitions: fill or supply something completely to the point of fullness or satisfaction
provide or equip something abundantly with a particular quality or feature
examples: The buffet table was replete with delicious international dishes
His speech was replete with references to classical literature
The new museum is replete with interactive displays and exhibits
The report was replete with errors and needed extensive revision

definitions: make an exact copy or reproduction of something in detail
repeat a scientific experiment or procedure to verify results or findings
examples: Scientists successfully replicated the DNA sequence in the laboratory
The artist replicated the famous painting with remarkable accuracy
Other researchers could not replicate the original experimental results
They replicated the study with a larger sample size

definitions: say or write something in response to a question or statement
respond to someone who has spoken to you or written to you
examples: She replied to all her emails before leaving the office
He replied that he would consider their generous offer carefully
When asked about her plans she replied with a smile
The minister replied to critics during the press conference yesterday

definitions: give a spoken or written account of something observed heard done or investigated
present oneself formally at a specified place or to a specified person
make a formal complaint or accusation about someone or something to authorities
examples: The journalist reported on the election results last night
She reports directly to the chief executive officer
All new employees must report to human resources on Monday
Soldiers were ordered to report for duty at dawn
Neighbors reported the suspicious activity to the police immediately
She reported her stolen credit card to the bank

definitions: lie down in a position of rest or sleep in a peaceful manner
place trust confidence or faith in a person or thing
examples: The cat reposes on the sunny windowsill every afternoon
His body reposes in the family cemetery plot
She reposes complete confidence in her financial advisor's judgment
The shareholders repose their trust in the new management team

definitions: move or place something in a different position or location than before
change the market position or public perception of a product brand or company
examples: The nurse repositioned the patient to prevent bedsores
They repositioned the furniture to create more open space
The company repositioned itself as a luxury brand last year
Marketing repositioned the product to appeal to younger consumers

definitions: be a symbol or expression of something abstract or concrete
act or speak officially for someone or a group in legal or formal contexts
depict or portray someone or something in art literature or other media
examples: The dove represents peace in many cultures around the world
These statistics represent only a small portion of cases
She represents several clients in intellectual property disputes
The senator represents the interests of her constituents
The painting represents a scene from Greek mythology
The actor represents the character with remarkable authenticity

definitions: subdue someone or something by force preventing expression or development
restrain prevent or inhibit an emotion impulse or desire from being expressed
examples: The government repressed all forms of political dissent harshly
The regime repressed the uprising with military force
She repressed her anger during the difficult meeting yesterday
He repressed his childhood memories for many years

definitions: officially postpone or cancel a punishment especially a death sentence
provide temporary relief from something difficult unpleasant or harmful
examples: The governor reprieved the prisoner hours before the scheduled execution
The court reprieved the sentence pending further investigation
Rain reprieved the drought-stricken farmers for a few weeks
The weekend provided a brief reprieve from work stress

definitions: rebuke someone formally and officially for their behavior or actions
express sharp disapproval or criticism of someone because of their behavior
examples: The board reprimanded the CEO for the financial irregularities
The teacher reprimanded students for cheating on the exam
His mother reprimanded him for coming home after midnight
The judge reprimanded the lawyer for unprofessional conduct

definitions: print more copies of a book or document that has already been published
produce a new edition or version of previously published written material
examples: The publisher decided to reprint the bestselling novel immediately
They reprinted the manual with corrections and updates
The magazine reprinted the controversial article with additional commentary
Universities often reprint classic texts for student use

definitions: repeat a musical phrase passage or song especially near the end
repeat or resume a role performance or activity after an interval
examples: The orchestra will reprise the main theme before the finale
The singer reprised the chorus one more time
She reprised her Broadway role for the movie adaptation
The band reprised their greatest hits at the reunion concert

definitions: express disappointment or displeasure with someone for their actions or behavior
criticize or blame someone for something they have done or failed to do
examples: She reproached him for forgetting their wedding anniversary again
His mother reproached him with a disappointed look
The committee reproached the chairman for his poor leadership
He reproached himself for not studying harder for the exam

definitions: produce offspring through biological processes of sexual or asexual reproduction
make a copy duplicate or representation of something especially in print or art
examples: Most mammals reproduce through sexual reproduction with live births
These bacteria reproduce rapidly under warm conditions
The printer can reproduce documents in full color
The artist reproduced the masterpiece with incredible detail

definitions: refuse to accept or be associated with something as valid or true
deny the truth or validity of something or refuse to acknowledge someone
examples: The candidate repudiated the extremist endorsement immediately
The company repudiated all claims of wrongdoing
He repudiated his earlier statements about the incident
The government repudiated the treaty signed by the previous administration

definitions: drive back an attacking military force by fighting against it
reject or refuse someone or something in a way that shows disgust
examples: The defenders repulsed three enemy attacks during the siege
The garrison repulsed the invaders at the city gates
She repulsed his romantic advances with clear displeasure
The committee repulsed all attempts to change the policy

definitions: buy something back that you previously owned or sold to someone else
acquire ownership of something again through a financial transaction or agreement
examples: The company plans to repurchase shares worth millions of dollars
He repurchased his childhood home after becoming successful
The museum repurchased the painting at the auction yesterday
Investors can repurchase bonds before their maturity date

definitions: generally consider or regard someone or something as having particular qualities
be known or regarded as having a particular characteristic or reputation
examples: Critics repute her as one of the finest writers alive
The restaurant is reputed to serve the best seafood downtown
This university is reputed for its excellent engineering program
He is reputed to be extremely wealthy and influential

definitions: politely or formally ask for something to be done or given
make a formal or official demand for something as a right or requirement
examples: She requested additional time to complete the project
Guests can request extra towels from the front desk
The court requested all relevant documents for the case
The committee requested his immediate resignation from the position

definitions: need something as necessary or essential for a particular purpose or result
officially demand or establish that something must be done or provided
examples: This recipe requires fresh herbs for the best flavor
Most plants require sunlight and water to grow properly
The law requires all drivers to wear seat belts
The job requires a bachelor's degree and five years experience

definitions: make an official request or demand for the use or supply of something
officially take possession of something especially for military purposes
examples: The department requisitioned new computers for all staff members
She requisitioned additional supplies from the central warehouse
The army requisitioned local buildings to house troops
Authorities requisitioned private vehicles during the emergency

definitions: run or perform something again especially a race test or computer program
show or broadcast a television program or movie again after its initial showing
examples: They had to rerun the experiment to verify the results
The technician will rerun the diagnostic test tomorrow morning
The network reruns classic sitcoms during the summer months
They rerun the documentary every year during the holidays

definitions: arrange for an event or appointment to take place at a different time
reorganize the timing or sequence of planned activities or payments
examples: We need to reschedule our meeting for next Tuesday
The airline rescheduled all flights due to bad weather
The bank agreed to reschedule the loan payments
They rescheduled the project timeline to meet new deadlines

definitions: revoke cancel or repeal a law decree or agreement officially
officially take back or withdraw an offer statement or decision
examples: The board voted to rescind the controversial policy immediately
Congress may rescind the tax increase next session
The company rescinded its job offer after the background check
She rescinded her resignation after receiving a promotion

definitions: save someone or something from a dangerous or distressing situation
retrieve or recover something from potential loss failure or abandonment
examples: Firefighters rescued three people from the burning building
The coast guard rescued sailors from the sinking ship
She rescued the company from bankruptcy with new investment
He rescued the old painting from the trash pile

definitions: study a subject systematically to establish facts and reach new conclusions
investigate something thoroughly to discover new information or verify existing knowledge
examples: Scientists research climate change effects on ocean ecosystems
She spent years researching medieval European history
The journalist researched the story for several months
Students must research their topics before writing essays

definitions: sell something that you have bought to another person or company
sell something again especially at a higher price for profit
examples: The store buys wholesale products to resell at retail prices
She resells vintage clothing through her online boutique
Ticket scalpers illegally resell concert tickets at inflated prices
He resold the property just six months after purchasing it

definitions: have qualities or appearance similar to someone or something else
have characteristics or features that are similar to another person or thing
examples: The daughter closely resembles her mother in appearance
This painting resembles the work of famous impressionist artists
His management style resembles that of his predecessor
The symptoms resemble those of a common cold

definitions: feel bitterness or indignation about something perceived as unfair treatment
feel angry or bitter about someone having something you think you deserve
examples: He resents having to work weekends while others don't
She resented the criticism of her work performance
They resent their neighbor's obvious wealth and success
He resents his brother for getting all the attention

definitions: keep something back for future use or a special purpose
arrange for a room table or seat to be kept for your use
refrain from expressing or showing feelings opinions or judgments
examples: We should reserve some funds for emergency expenses
The company reserves the right to change prices
Please reserve a table for four at the restaurant
She reserved two tickets for tonight's performance
He reserved judgment until all facts were presented
She reserves her opinions for private conversations only

definitions: set or adjust something again to a different position or state
restore a device or system to its original or default settings
examples: The doctor reset the broken bone in her arm
Remember to reset your clocks for daylight saving time
He reset the computer to factory settings yesterday
You need to reset your password for security reasons

definitions: settle in a new place after leaving a previous home or country
help people establish themselves in a new place to live permanently
examples: The family resettled in Canada after fleeing their homeland
Many refugees resettled in neighboring countries last year
The agency helps resettle displaced families in safe areas
The government resettled thousands of flood victims
